Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Meghan Marie Cromie of Texas Tech University to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at Nanjing Medical University in Nanjing, China. The project title is "Determination of Persistent Organic Pollutants in Township Waters of China and Their Ecological Impact." The host scientist is Dr. Shou-Lin Wang, M.D., Ph.D.

With a growing population and a heavy reliance on industry and agriculture, China has experienced an increase in the concentration of persistent organic pollutants (POPs) being released into surface waters, specifically in townships located in Eastern China near Nanjing. With higher cancer incidences near this region, it is this project's hope to identify and quantify the POPs responsible for this problem. This study aims to address these research gaps by determining POPs and identify possible sources of contamination throughout the region using different approaches, including biological and chemical techniques.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the Fellow intends on mentoring and training a female, senior undergraduate student from the University. Through mentoring, the Fellow will provide training that will prepare a student to eventually carry out her own independent research, which will hopefully build on data collected over the course of the summer. In addition, the time in China will be used to present the Fellow's master's and doctoral research projects at the host university, as well as neighboring universities to increase networking and enhance potential international collaborations. The research conducted in China will also be used by the host collaborator's lab for epidemiological studies to determine relationships between contamination sites and townships with increased incidences of cancer. Finally, upon the Fellow's return to the United States, she plans on presenting her research at a conference, publishing with the host collaborator and implementing some of the findings in her dissertation research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The influence of polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) on environmental and human exposure is of great concern in China. PAHs are formed from combustion processes primarily involving the burning of wood and coal, (Li et al., 2012; Ou et al., 2010) with some from petroleum origins as well (Hui et al., 2009; Ou et al., 2010). Although studies have found PAH levels to be below China’s drinking water health standards, the continual exposure and mixture with other anthropogenic compounds could still result in unwanted health effects after long-term exposure. The role of contaminants in ecological systems and overall human health is of concern considering the ever present need to conserve and recycle water. Recently, it has been reported that townships located in North Jiangsu, a southeastern province of China, have observed an increase in cancer incidence. More specifically, the city of Huai’an has been the subject of several studies due to its greater cancer incidences and mortality rates compared to the rest of the country (Liu et al., 2007; Sun et al., 2007; Gao et al., 2002). Based on these findings, the goal of Dr. Shou-Lin Wang of the Nanjing Medical University's resarch group was to identify and quantify the PAHs and metabolites present in surface waters and human urine collected from areas with high tumor incidences (Huai’an) and low tumor incidences (Xuzhou), to further elucidate the possible role of environmental PAH exposure and cancer incidence.  

                As expected, total PAHs were greatest in Huai’an. This difference could be explained by the enhanced combustion of coal and wood in the area, thereby influencing PAH concentrations in the water. When examining cancer in subjects from both Huai’an and Xuzhou, we found that more people were diagnosed with gastrointestinal cancer in Huai’an than those in Xuzhou, suggesting that PAHs might be associated with the enhanced gastrointestinal cancer incidence. A study conducted by Drug et al. in cell culture found that PAHs complex with the gut, thereby increasing PAH bioavailability and possibly enhancing the overall toxicity (2011). When examining the urine of the sample populations, we found that Huai’an had the greatest total urinary metabolites. Similar trends were observed in metabolites of PAH in urine and PAH in surface waters, with the highest PAH levels measured in Huai’an. Finally, the relationship between PAH metabolites in urine and cancer incidence had a similar trend with both being the greatest in Huai’an. The results of this preliminary study provide some evidence that PAHs might play a potential role in the increased incidence of gastrointestinal cancer in Huai’an, but further testing is necessary to fully elucidate this phenomena occurring in Huai’an. Moreover, this research was further used by my host institution upon my departure for epidemiological studies that investigated additional compounds acting as possible sources of cancer in Huai’an.

Overall, the National Science Foundation East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes Fellowship provided me with invaluable research, as well as mentoring opportunities. Much of the research conducted for this project was done with graduate students from my host lab and department, which helped facilitate strong and long-lasting relationships. I also mentored a female undergraduate student that continues to work in Dr. Wang’s lab. Additionally, I was given an opportunity to discuss graduate school in the US to upper-level classman, allowing me to better clarify the reality of college life in the US and dispel possible misconceptions.
